course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Physics and the Modern Society
course.description: This course is for students with no physics background. Course content: Principle of scientific theories and methods, Aristotle's law, Newtonian mechanics. Thermal physics, heat engine, energy crisis and global warming. Nature of waves and the physics of hearing and vision. Electricity and magnetism, electromagnetic waves and telecommunication. Relativity, quantum physics, nuclear energy and semiconductor. Developments and outlook of contemporary physics.
course.exclusions: Level 3 or above in HKDSE 1/2x Physics or HKDSE 1x Physics; any PHYS courses at 1100-level or above

reviews.author: Samson10504
reviews.title: A good introductory course with GOOD GRADE!!!
reviews.comment_content:
01 Physics and the Modern Society
02 Energy
03 Entertainment and Daily Application
04 New materials and physics
05 Microscopy and Nontechnology
06 Information Technology
07 Environmental Issues
08 Medical Applications
09 Disasters
10 Universe
11 The Future and Unsolved Problems
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor mainly teaches according to the PowerPoint slides and play videos.

You may say this course is relying on how hard you study. Since the exams are based on the lecture notes, lecture polling and tutorial questions. Make sure you go through all of them and you should be fine to get a satisfactory grade!
reviews.comment_grading: Quite good. I didn't study a lot and got a B+. Since it is online examination this year, I can refer to the notes while answering the questions. But you should understand all the concepts because you have limited time to do. You can hardly finished all the questions if you didn't understand them before the examinations.
reviews.comment_workload: 2 lecture and 1 tutorial in a week. You have to attain the tutorial session because it counts attendance. Lecture also has polls which counts grades as well. Make sure you attend both of them to ensure your attendance marks.

reviews.author: ptrknow
reviews.comment_content:
Note that the syllabus is changed this year. In a nutshell, the mathematical stuff is no longer required, but there will be more technical stuff contextually detailed.

The course contents are separately taught by four professors, mainly Ng Yee Fai and Lin Nian. To be personal, the syllabus is broad, but without systematic organization. (And I think many things in this course are not Year-1 level at all. Although the professors are just attempting to give a brief account on those things, they are still hard to comprehend.)

Here is basically what we have to learn in each chapter. The level of difficulty of each chapter (from my point of view) for a physics beginner is also indicated.

Ng Yee Fai part:
1. Energy ⭐⭐⭐
- Mechanical Energy (Potential Energy, Kinetic Energy, Work-Energy Theorem)
- Conservation of Energy
- Sources of Energy (Solar, Wind, Tidal, Geothermal, Hydrogen, Plasma)
- Nuclear Power (Fission, Fusion, Nuclear Reactors, Mass-Energy Equivalence)

This chapter is a bit difficult when it comes to plasma and nuclear power, which constitute around half of the chapter.

2. Daily Applications (A) ⭐⭐⭐⭐
- Thermodynamics
Application 1: Heat Engine (e.g. Internal Combustion Engine)
Application 2: Heat Pumps (e.g. Refrigerator and Air-con)

- Electromagnetism
。Electric charge (Applications: Photocopiers, laser printers, 3d printers)
。Capacitors (Applications: RAM, Touch Screens, Supercapacitor bus)
。Electromagnetic Induction (Applications: Transformers, Inductive Charging, Electric Guitar, Motors, Generators, Hybrid Automobiles, Maglev)

As a physics beginner, I took several days to at least understand what all the text in the slides of this chapter is talking about. Not easy at all.

3. Daily Applications (B) ⭐⭐⭐⭐
- Mechanics
。Acceleration (Application: MEMS)
。Oscillation (Application: Electronic Clocks)

- Optics
。Polarization (Application: 3D-Viewing, LCD)

- Modern Physics
。Photoelectric effect (Application: CCD)
。Molecules and Condensed Matters (Application: LED, OLED)
。Atoms
    1. Laser (Application: Holography)
    2. Atomic clocks (Application: GPS)

Same as the previous chapter, I took many efforts to understand what the fuck is going on.

4. Medical Applications⭐⭐⭐
- Waves
。Sound waves (Application: Ultrasound Imaging)

- Optics
。Fiber optics (Application: Endoscopy)

- Modern Physics
。Laser (Application: LASIK, PRK)
。X-ray (Application: X-ray Imaging, CAT)
。Pair Annihilation (Application: PET)
。NMR (Application: MRI)

As time passed by, the chapters of Ng Yee Fai part became easier. For this chapter, X-ray, pair annihilation and NMR are the more difficult parts, comprising a large portion of the chapter. But at least, way easier to understand compared to daily applications!

5. Disasters⭐⭐⭐
- Stellar Impact (e.g. Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9, the Cretaceous extinction, The Chelyabinsk Asteroid, The Yunnan Fireball, A/2017 U1)

- Earthquake (Seismic waves, Earth's internal layers, earthquake causes, magnitude scales)

- Nuclear weapons
。Atomic bombs (Little Boy, The Gadget, Fat Man)
。Hydrogen Bomb (Fusion Bomb)
。Aftermath of nuclear explosions

- Nuclear Reactor Accidents (The Three Mile Island Accident, The Chernobyl Accident, The Fukushima Accident)

Largely related to the chapter of Energy (the first chapter listed). The earthquake and nuclear weapon parts are relatively difficult, composing a large part of this chapter.

6. Environmental Issues ⭐⭐
a. Solar Radiation
b. Greenhouse Effect
c. The Keeling Curve
d. Global Warming
e. Carbon footprint

The easiest chapter, throughout the WHOLE COURSE, because they are mainly senior level Geography stuff, with less details.

Each chapter has a slide of around 80-100 pages. Some of the pages are just video, pictures and demonstrations, but most of them will be wordy contextual details.

Lin Nian part:
1. Introduction⭐
Shit intro.

2. New Material and Physics ⭐⭐⭐⭐

Current Materials
- Silicon
(Application: PN-junction diode, PNP-junction transistor)
- Carbon (Graphite and Graphene)
(Application: Flexible display, graphene nanoribbons, carbon nanotube)

Future Materials
- Metamaterials (Invisible cloaking, negative refractive index)
- Quantum materials (Quantum hall effect)

Supplement: Superconductors

3. Microscopy and Nanotechnology⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Microscopy
- History
- Properties of light (EM wave, diffraction)
- X-ray crystallography
- Double-slit experiment
- Scanning Electron Microscopy
- Transmission Electron Microscopy
- Quantum tunneling effects (Application: Scanning Tunneling Microscopy)
- Atomic force microscopy

Nanotech
- Definition
- Damascus
- Properties at nanometer scale (subatomic scale)
  Example: Gold
- Quantum confinement
- Application: sunscreens
- Quantum Dot displays
- Nano-fabrication (Lithography: E-beam, Focused Ion beam, Molecular beam epitaxy)

4. Information Technology and Physics ⭐⭐⭐⭐
- Magnetic data storage
。Magnetism (Spin, Curie Temperature, Magnetic domains, etc.)
。Data Storage (GMR, TMR, MTJ)

- Quantum computer
。Uncertainty Principle
。Particle and Wave Duality
。Superposition
。Qubit
。Advantages of quantum computer

- Quantum communication
。quantum entanglement

5. Future and Unsolved Problems⭐
Quantum gravity, particle masses, quantum measurement, turbulence, dark energy, dark matter, complexity, matter-antimatter asymmetry, friction, arrow of time

Just some brief introduction to the above unsolved problems and ending of the course.

I had many question marks on my head whenever I took a seat in Lin Nian's lecture. I could not even understand his notes. Of course they are more concise than Ng Yee Fai's, but the notes gave no explanation (just some random combinations of description, pictures and mathematical equations).

"Ahhhhhh..... Mathematics is intrinsically fucking beautiful......"

====GUEST LECTURES====

Liu Tao: Elementary Particles and Standard Model
?????????????????????????????????????????????

Wang Yi: Universe and Cosmology
I can say I know what is going on, but I cannot say so either.......

Two documentaries:
- The Big Bang Machine
- Into the Universe with Stephen Hawking

Long documentaries. I think I do not really love physics (or science). I found the documentaries uninteresting, but sure, way more understandable than the NOTES of the guest lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I don't know why, but I just couldn't help sleeping in the lectures. The lectures, objectively speaking, are not really boring. Yeah, I still fell asleep during the lectures, very often.

I also found myself unable to follow what the professors were teaching. But for Ng Yee Fai, I could still drop down some notes and then try to understand afterwards. While for Lin Nian, well, I couldn't find any main points from his speaking.

(Oh, I coincidentally discovered that Lin Nian is / was in charge of PHYS 1314 and the course reviews there have more comments about him, the first two of which are indeed accurate..)

Tutorial: Ng Ka Long
Pure wastage of time. But you still have to attend the tutorial, because it counts towards your final grade. I should have swapped to other sessions.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Tutorial Attendance

70% Final Exam
- 75 MC questions in 3 hours

The questions are just asking what the notes and tutorial questions are telling you, but you definitely cannot answer if you don't do the revision. (基本上就系，識就識，唔識就唔識。有溫同無溫嘅分別。)

Most people could finish the paper within 45 minutes (or even 30). Maybe the professors should have asked 200 questions, say.

No statistics are provided. The grading should be not bad (Ng Yee Fai said that he normally would give out B+).
reviews.comment_workload:
As a guy who didn't take DSE physics before, it is a strenuous task to understand and REMEMBER the stuff on the notes. This requires constant efforts throughout the semester.

But if you are not intended to do well in this course, then the workload is very light, because you can just go for tutorial and final exam. And this column should be an 'A' for you.

reviews.author: g2s
reviews.comment_content:
There're quite a few chapters and topics covered in this course, but they're all discussed on a surface level. Rote memorization is all you need in this course.

Chapters:
1. History, Methodology and Bird View
2. Energy
3. Documentary: The Story of Energy / BBC
4. Entertainment and Various Daily Applications
5. New Materials and Physics
6. Microscopy and Nanotechnology
7. Information Technology and Physics
8. Documentary: The Story of Information / BBC
9. Environmental Issues
10. Medical Applications
11. Disasters
12. Universe and Cosmology
13. Future and Unsolved Problems

Topics:
Principle of scientific theories and methods, Aristotle's law, Newtonian mechanics, thermal physics, heat engine, energy crisis, global warming, nature of waves, the physics of hearing and vision, electricity and magnetism, electromagnetic waves, telecommunication, relativity, quantum physics, nuclear energy, semiconductor, developments and outlook of contemporary physics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching... leaves much to be desired. The professor, with a typical American accent, is easy to be understood. The issue is that his teaching doesn't exactly make people want to listen - his voice is monotonous, and while he doesn't really read from the slides word for word, the content is virtually the same.

If the professor sounded boring, then the TA must've sounded bored. To his credit, however, he does put in effort into explaining things, both with his words and with MS Paint.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% - lecture participation through iPRS MCQ
15% - tutorial participation through iPRS MCQ
15% - tutorial iPRS MCQ correctness
60% - final exam (90 MCQ in 90 minutes, closed-book)
Two of the lowest lecture scores and the lowest tutorial score are dropped.

All things considered, the grading is quite lenient. Though I didn't get all of the iPRS questions correct, and only started studying perhaps a day before the final, I was able to get a B+. Not trying to flex - I'm normally terrible at physics - rote memorization really is all you need in this course. Some iPRS questions even appear in the final exam.

I compiled this semester's lecture and tutorial answers into two pdf files below so you won't need to spend half a minute each question looking for the answer from lecture notes (or peeking at others' screens).
reviews.comment_workload:
2 lectures and 1 tutorial every week. One final exam. That's all.

I'd imagine most people would at least get a B, so if you're hoping to get an A+, you'd probably want to spend at least a little bit of effort into reviewing the material, like some people that I know have done.

However, tbh, the course is still very boring. And you can choose to watch the recording at two times the speed.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 5%
Discussion 5%
Group Presentation 10%
Tutorials (quizzes and essays) 20%
Midterm 25%
Final 35%
1. Got full marks in Participation
2. Miss some weeks' discussion but still above mean a lot
3. This part might be around mean (not released),  but it is true that our group didn't do pretty well in this part
4. almost full marks in both quizzes and essays (around 96%)
5. Midterm above mean 10 points  (100 points in total and SD not released)
6. Final above mean 1SD
Finally got B...
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not light!!!!!!!
First of all, attendance for every course would be recorded.
Second, you must attend tutorials each week and do the in-class quiz and after-class essay.... every week a short essay!!! and on Friday!!!! quite frustrating!!!!
And there's also a group presentation.
You also need to participate in the CANVAS discussion every week if you want to get a great score.
Midterm puls a final.
In brief, if you just want a leng grade common core, just skip this one. And if you need to take a physics class due to ssci requirements, just find any other higher level physics class such as phys 1111/1112.

reviews.author: Stephen Chow
reviews.title: Review of PHY1001
reviews.comment_content:
Topics covered:
History, Methodology and Bird View 

New Materials and Physics

Microscopy and Nanotechnology 

Information Technology and Physics 

Energy 

Entertainment 

Various Daily Applications

Environmental Issues

Medical Applications 

Disasters 

The topics covered are fair, but they are a bit boring. Some topics like disasters and environmental issues
will be easier to catch up for those who have 0 concepts in PHY. Other topics are slightly difficult to handle for newbies.
reviews.comment_teaching:
My instructor was Prof. Lin. He is a patient and friendly professor who is willing to explain the concepts to you one by one.
He likes to show students YouTube videos and demos to demonstrate Physics concepts. And I think they do help as the YouTube videos generally summarized all the things covered in the lesson.
Although Prof. Lin's accent is a little bit strong, you will get used to it easily. And tbh, you can understand him if you follow him closely.

I also did attend a few of Prof. Li's lessons for reference. He is very good at explaining the concepts and he would elaborate much more. He will go through much more of the basic Physics concepts which I think it's very useful in helping people without a Physics background to understand.
He's also nice and friendly.

In summary, both professors are awesome. If you want to have a better understanding of the core concepts, go for Prof. Li. If you just want to understand the facts, go for Prof. Lin.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is pretty fair.
Attendance is necessary for both lectures and tutorials. Attendance is taken based on answering polls via Zoom due to the online lesson arrangement.

Attendance: 40% of the final grade
Final Exam: 60%
(if I rmb correctly haha)

My final was an open book exam, all MCs, and straight forward. Some MCs are covered in tutorials

If you want a nice grade, be a good student. Attend all lectures and tutorials and REVISE.

Since I really suck at Physics, I will revise the lecture materials after taught. (like you better understand the concepts, like do some google if necessary. It really helps, altho it's the most tedious part)

A range
reviews.comment_workload:
In terms of assignment,
0 workload, 0 assignment
--> only have to attend lessons and tutorials

In terms of exams
--> only one final exam
BUT,
You should revise the materials from time to time. Like don't leave them aside or else you will be in HUGE trouble(especially you're bad in PHY).

Since the materials provided in the lectures are really brief and the profs won't dwell into the details and core concepts, sometimes it's quite difficult to understand the lectures.

Have faith in yourself, hard work pays off!

reviews.author: Boris Lo
reviews.title: Good course, but bad teaching
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture 1-2 History, Methodology and Bird View
Lecture 3-4 New Materials and Physics
Lecture 5-7 Microscopy and Nanotechnology
Lecture 8-9 Information Technology and Physics 10-11 Energy
Lecture 12-13 Entertainment
Lecture 14-15 Various Daily Applications
Lecture 16-17 Environmental Issues
Lecture 18-19 Medical Applications
Lecture 20-21 Disasters
Lecture 22 Future and Unsolved Problems
Lecture 23 Term Review
As an SBM student, I find the content is very interesting as the topics are all related to our daily life. It is quite easy as the course requires no calculation, only understanding and memorization.
reviews.comment_teaching: Honestly, I do respect every professor but this guy is ridiculous. His accent makes it impossible to listen to the lecture. I seriously doubt his spoken English as well, as he can hardly say a simple sentence fluently. Not a single word could be understood so I just study the materials myself or resort to Google if there is anything I do not understand.  It turns out that paying attention to lectures is not necessary and effective.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is pretty decent, I miss one tutorial, which costs me 3%. The score of the final exam is not released but I think I did pretty well. I end up getting an A. Very good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light, you do not have any assignments or mid-term examinations. All you need to do is participate in the polling during lectures and tutorials and work hard for the final exam. The course is recommended if you are taking 18 creds or doing a part-time intern. Good grade and almost no workload.
The online exam is open-booked, but you still need to study hard otherwise you would not have enough time

reviews.comment_teaching: You will sleep if you feel sleepy during the lectures as the voice is quite flat throughout the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 5%
Discussion 5%
Group Presentation 10%
Tutorials (quizzes and essays) 20%
Midterm 25%
Final 35%

Score higher marks in midterm and final will definitely help to boost your grade. There are multiple choice questions and essay questions (asking operating steps, technology used etc) included in the exams. Memorizing the content will help to score higher marks. By posting and replying to the questions in the discussion board, you can earn weekly mark for discussion.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload can consider as slightly above average as there are weekly discussion on canvas, group presentation to prepare.

Besides, there is weekly essay to be completed during tutorial lesson in each week. Sometimes the question can be hard as you can't find the solution in the lecture notes. You need to search for more in depth knowledge on the website or any other sources.

reviews.author: dm07
reviews.comment_content:
1. History, Methodology and Bird View
2. Energy
3. Entertainment and Various Daily Applications
4. New Materials and Physics
5. Microscopy and Nanotechnology
6. Information Technology and Physics
7. Environmental Issues
8. Medical Applications
9. Disasters

The content is interesting to some extent but it felt less of a physics course and more of a general knowledge course into how things around us work. There aren't any calculations and formulae to remember so it's pretty chill especially if you don't like math. The lecture slides are just filled with information and he played a couple of documentaries.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Bradley tries to make class interesting and engaging by using demos but most of the time the class is pretty boring. He reads right off the slides and his voice can make you very sleepy. He speaks pretty slowly so you can easily rewatch the lectures on 2x the speed.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 25% - MCQ questions and essay questions.
Final 35% - the announcement said it would be cumulative but only one question was asked from chapters covered before the midterm. MCQ questions and essay questions.
Participation 5% - IPRS questions
Discussion 5% - Canvas. You can ask relevant questions on the materials discussed and even answer other students' questions.
Group Presentation 10% - each group needs to choose a topic of their liking from any of the 9 chapters depending on what is assigned. It either has to be different or go beyond the lecture materials.
Tutorials (quizzes and essays) 20% - IPRS and one essay question which needs to be submitted by 9 p.m. on the same day.

Completely changed the grading pattern as classes were all face to face. Online classes last year were much more lenient.

Stats:
Midterm - Mean: 50.26  Median: 48
                 High: 82  Low : 0
                 High: 82
                 Upper Quartile: 65.5  Lower Quartile: 38

Final - Mean: 63.95 Median: 69.5
           High: 94   Low: 0
           Upper Quartile: 80.25  Lower Quartile: 50.75

Not sure about the rest but the IPRS is pretty easy. The essays grades are never constant as it is marked by different TAs.
reviews.comment_workload:
Lots of work to do. The midterm had 15 mcq questions and it each was worth 3 points?!! The essay questions were even worse and it requires a lot of rote learning and memorising to score. Absolutely horrified by the weightage of each question. Final was the same and again required a lot of memorising. The lecture slides are really long and filled with tons of information so its hard to memorise.
I never did any of the canvas discussion and it didn't hurt my grade much. Group presentation marking scheme is weird as hell and complicated. The tutorials were the absolute worst. The essay questions were annoying and no concrete feedback was given after grading, so you had no clue as to how to improve. Hated those tutorials!

reviews.comment_teaching: It was quite interesting with all those demos/ experiments during the lessons within the add drop period. However, the lessons after the add drop period are becoming boring and many people are starting not to pay full attention in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair Grading

Participation 5%
Discussion 5%
Group Presentation 10%
Tutorials (quizzes and essays) 20%
Midterm exam 25%
Final exam 35%

Participation & Discussion:
- I participated in all discussion forums every week so the mark should be fine

Group Presentation: 8/10

Tutorials:
- IPRS all FULL; Most Essays:: 9-10/10

Midterm exam: above mean around 10 marks  

Final exam: mean mark
Final grade: B...
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very HIGH!
You will have to finish an essay every week during the whole semester.
You will need to attend all the lessons since there is IPRS for all lectures and tutorials (no skipping class)
The group presentation is also a burden as you will have to prepare for a topic that is discussed in class and have to do a lot of research for that topic
For the canvas discussion forum, you will have to participate every week in order to secure a good participation mark.

All in all, this common core has transformed into a bad cc and it is not recommended to reg it if you aim high for your GPA.

4. Energy issues

6. Household Applications
7. Medical
8. Environmental issues
9. Disasters
10. General introduction and future outlook of PHYSICS.

You have to link the physics concepts of mechanics, thermal physics, electromagnetism, quantum physics, and relativity to the chapters!! The content is easy to understand though some principles might be boring. No calculations but a lot of memorisation. The professor gives the PowerPoint or notes enough to prepare for the examination.
reviews.comment_teaching: This semester is online teaching, and both instructors are very patient and eager to explain the concepts and misunderstandings in zoom classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lecture polling 10%
Tutorial attendance 20%
Tutorial iPRS 20%
Final exam 50%

The final exam, all MCs,  is a closed book with the instructor’s invigilation. You need to turn on the camera and show it to the laptop and desk. You cannot change your MC answers once you proceed to the next question.

Good grade! I got A- even though I just studied the notes and didn’t attend the lectures. It is easy to get an A range if you attend the tutorial sections.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. There are no assignments, and you only have to attend the lectures and tutorials to take attendance and answer questions.

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Li is so nice and friendly. He is willing to answer questions during the lecture. He is good at explaining basic concepts and this makes you understand the theory easily. He also provided a term review PowerPoints notes for us to have a quick review in different topics. I suggest that people with no physics background can go to Prof Li's sessions so that they can have better understanding in physics theories.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading:
In-class zoom polling (MCQ): 10% by answer
Tutorial (MCQ): 20% by attendance, 20% by answer
Closed-book Final (MCQ): 50%

Some questions in final exam are selected from tutorial sessions so revise all PowerPoints notes and tutorial questions can help you prepare the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
Few polling questions during lectures. The MC questions are included in the PowerPoints which are given few days before the lectures. You can prepare the questions before the lectures.

There are 10 MC questions in each tutorials, revising the contents taught in that week. The questions is easy to answer if you pay attention in the lectures. The TA may briefly revise the PowerPoints with you before the iPRS questions.

reviews.comment_grading: The grading seems fair. The exam wasn't very difficult. The exam borrows questions from your tutorial sessions so remember to revise them.
reviews.comment_workload: We had to answer zoom MCs every lesson but we got the ppt slides one week before so have sufficient time to prepare. Other than that we have to do 10 mc for tutorial every week. No mid-term just the final exam

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Foreman is a nice guy. He is willing to answer your questions and have a clear accent.
HOWEVER, his voice is so magical that it has the power to drive you into drowsiness and let you fall asleep. What makes thing worse is he will follow the PowerPoint strictly which makes the lectures boring.

reviews.comment_grading:
There are in total three elements involves in the grading system.

1. Lecture participation (10%)
- There will be some IPRS questions during the lectures and by just doing them you can get the participation point (no matter right or wrong). Two of the worst lectures will not be counted. (That means you can skip at most 2 lectures)
2. Tutorial (15% participation + 15% correctness)
- Each tutorial there will be 10 MC to be done. Open notes, open discussion, open Google. So scoring high in this shall not be a problem. One of the worst tutorial will not be counted.
3. Final Exam (60%)
- This year there is in total 90 MC to be done in 90 mins
- Most of the MC are just factual recall, do not involve in any maths.
- around 30 MC are from the IPRS questions, tutorials and sample exam provided to you. Revising them are important.

My grade: A
Lecture : 10/10
Tutorial: 29/30
Final: Grade is not provided but I guess I get at most get 3 MC wrong.
So I guess in order to score an A+ you have to score full in all three categories.
reviews.comment_workload:
You can say that there is no workload.
Just need to go through the notes and Google during tutorials and do some revisions before the exam.

reviews.author: Sonic12
reviews.title: Review of PHYS1001
reviews.comment_content:
1. History, Methodology, and Bird View
2. New Materials
3. Microscopy and Nanotechnology
4. Information Technology
5. Energy
6. Entertainment
7. Various Daily Applications
8. Environmental Issues
9. Medical Applications
10. Disasters
11. Future and Unsolved Problems

Very mild introduction to the overall physics area. Don't be intimidated by the word "physics". In this course, there's almost no calculation.

Just understand which properties are proportional or inversely proportional in the formulas given in the lectures. Then, the rest are more or less related to memorization of the details.

I would say if you have any kind of physics background or know some stories about the advancement of physics(ex. Einstein, quantum mechanics, thermodynamics, etc) it would be helpful especially for understanding "information technology and physics" and "various daily applications" part.

However, if you don't know a lot about physics that's okay you can catch up it's not that hard.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Jensen is the nicest and patient professor I've ever met.

The professor literally tries to serve every question he got during the lectures and even spends extra time answering questions by opening office hours.

I see that he genuinely tries to make students understand the physics concepts and he did a fine job.

If you don't know anything about physics don't skip the lectures and listen carefully to how the professor explains it.

Lastly, if you have any doubts or questions about the concepts don't hesitate to ask him during the lectures or after the lectures. He will definitely answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class Polling (10% by "correct" MCQ answers)
Tutorial iPRS (20% by "correct" MCQ answers + 20% by attendance)
Final Examination (50% MCQ)

For the in-class polling, sometimes there can be somewhat ambiguous question options.
If there is, tell the professor it is ambiguous.
Sometimes he will correct it and sometimes he will make other options correct also.

Sometimes the TAs grade polls wrongly so if you have any doubts send an email to them or the professor they will correct it.

For in-class polling and tutorials, there are single-answer questions and multiple answer questions but the multiple answer one is a lot more. So look carefully when you solve them.

For the final exam, we had 40 single choice MCQ and 30 multiple choice MCQ (70 MCQs in total) and we can know which problems are single choice or which are multiple-choice. Some questions are taken from tutorials and in-class polls.

For reference, it was open book(notes) but internet searching by electronic devices is not allowed.

(the poll and tutorial grading is started from lecture 5 and tutorial 2, after the add/drop period)

It is not difficult overall speaking. It is appropriate for students who haven't studied physics before, since it just covers basic knowledge for each topic without the need for calculation.
1. Energy issues and physics
2. Entertainment and physics
3. New materials and physics
4. Microscopy and nanotechnology
5. Information technology and physics
6. Environmental issues and physics
7. Medical/health and physics
8. Disasters and physics
9. Universe and cosmology
reviews.comment_teaching: It is quite boring tbh. The professor uses a tone without intonation throughout the lectures. If the lectures do not count iprs, I would not attend the lectures definitely.
reviews.comment_grading:
iprs during lectures         5%
iprs during tutorials       30%
final                               65%
Make sure you attend all the iprs during lectures and tutorials. Every single iprs counts mark. I got nearly full marks for the iprs, but not sure about my mark in the final exam. The final exam is a bit rush as it requires students to complete 60 mc within 1 hour, so make sure you have your own cheat sheet beforehand.

I finally got B- in this subject. I think it is fair since I just simply studied all the materials one day before the exam.
reviews.comment_workload: It has a relatively lower workload compared to other courses. It requires iprs during lectures as well as tutorials. However, it doesn't have a midterm or any quizzes. You just simply need to study all the materials before the final exam, and it will be in a multiple-choice format.

reviews.author: Miracles
reviews.title: Boring course
reviews.comment_content: This course will teach you some physics related knowledge without any calculation. If you didn't learn physics in the past, do not expect this course will make you know more about physics stuffs.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good professor comparing to FOREMAN.
At the very beginning, I was taught by FOREMAN. After about half an hour in the first lesson, I know that I must swap to any other lecturers. So, I was taught by NG for the rest of the lessons.

NG managed a good interaction with his students in the chatroom. He will response some fun comments and make us less boring in the lessons.

However, there are so many things we have to learn in this course and making the whole teaching become boring. There are only limited relations between lectures. The things you learn in the last lecture have no use in this lecture and so on. So, the professor always spend time to explain things in detail for every lecture. When the professor try to explain somethings, there are so many terms you never heard before and you don't know how it works. For the first time, you may feel confused. After several time, you will lose your mood to focus in the lecture.

It maybe my problem only... So, at least, I think NG is better if you really want to learn some physics stuffs in this course as he can explain to you in detail. MOST IMPORTANTLY, his lessons have much more fun than FOREMAN's.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% tutorial participation
5% lecture participation
65% final exam

For participation:
You can get full mark if you participate all the poll questions as you will get marks no matter you answer them correctly or not.

For the exam, we have an open book MC only exam this semester. 4 days before the exam, it's my first time to read the lecture notes seriously. I had never read those notes before that day. And overall I got B- for this course. So, I think the grading should be quite good if you able to focus in the boring lectures and prepare well before the exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Answering poll questions in the lecture and tutorial.
2. Doing revision before the Exam.

As there are no short question in the exam for this semester, the workload is very low if you are not aim for getting A.

reviews.author: Tommy0234_1011
reviews.comment_content:
Ng Yee Fai part:
1. Energy ⭐⭐⭐
- Mechanical Energy (Potential Energy, Kinetic Energy, Work-Energy Theorem)
- Conservation of Energy
- Sources of Energy (Solar, Wind, Tidal, Geothermal, Hydrogen, Plasma)
- Nuclear Power (Fission, Fusion, Nuclear Reactors, Mass-Energy Equivalence)

This chapter is a bit difficult when it comes to plasma and nuclear power, which constitute around half of the chapter.

2. Daily Applications (A) ⭐⭐⭐⭐
- Thermodynamics
Application 1: Heat Engine (e.g. Internal Combustion Engine)
Application 2: Heat Pumps (e.g. Refrigerator and Air-con)

- Electromagnetism
。Electric charge (Applications: Photocopiers, laser printers, 3d printers)
。Capacitors (Applications: RAM, Touch Screens, Supercapacitor bus)
。Electromagnetic Induction (Applications: Transformers, Inductive Charging, Electric Guitar, Motors, Generators, Hybrid Automobiles, Maglev)

As a physics beginner, I took several days to at least understand what all the text in the slides of this chapter is talking about. Not easy at all.

3. Daily Applications (B) ⭐⭐⭐⭐
- Mechanics
。Acceleration (Application: MEMS)
。Oscillation (Application: Electronic Clocks)

- Optics
。Polarization (Application: 3D-Viewing, LCD)

- Modern Physics
。Photoelectric effect (Application: CCD)
。Molecules and Condensed Matters (Application: LED, OLED)
。Atoms
    1. Laser (Application: Holography)
    2. Atomic clocks (Application: GPS)

Same as the previous chapter, I took many efforts to understand what the fuck is going on.

4. Medical Applications⭐⭐⭐
- Waves
。Sound waves (Application: Ultrasound Imaging)

- Optics
。Fiber optics (Application: Endoscopy)

- Modern Physics
。Laser (Application: LASIK, PRK)
。X-ray (Application: X-ray Imaging, CAT)
。Pair Annihilation (Application: PET)
。NMR (Application: MRI)

As time passed by, the chapters of Ng Yee Fai part became easier. For this chapter, X-ray, pair annihilation and NMR are the more difficult parts, comprising a large portion of the chapter. But at least, way easier to understand compared to daily applications!

5. Disasters
- Stellar Impact (e.g. Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9, the Cretaceous extinction, The Chelyabinsk Asteroid, The Yunnan Fireball, A/2017 U1)

- Earthquake (Seismic waves, Earth's internal layers, earthquake causes, magnitude scales)

- Nuclear weapons
。Atomic bombs (Little Boy, The Gadget, Fat Man)
。Hydrogen Bomb (Fusion Bomb)
。Aftermath of nuclear explosions

- Nuclear Reactor Accidents (The Three Mile Island Accident, The Chernobyl Accident, The Fukushima Accident)

Largely related to the chapter of Energy (the first chapter listed). The earthquake and nuclear weapon parts are relatively difficult, composing a large part of this chapter.

6. Environmental Issues
a. Solar Radiation
b. Greenhouse Effect
c. The Keeling Curve
d. Global Warming
e. Carbon footprint

The easiest chapter, throughout the WHOLE COURSE, because they are mainly senior level Geography stuff, with less details.

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Li's teaching is fine, and his english is good that is clear and easily understandable, so I'll say it's ok to keep attentive during the lectures. Since this is a introductory course, he had to skip many contents such as mathematical proofs and give everything a brief introduction, and he explained the concepts well, as these are often associated with concrete examples instead on abstract theories. I still found the materials somewhat interesting as the applications sounds familiar (such as GPS, computers, clocks, Air conditioners, power plants).

Tutorials 30% (attendence)

Final Exam 65% (online, open book, 90mins, 40 Single-answer MC and 30 Multiple-answer MC)

However, thanks to stupid ZOOM, I was stuck in the waiting room so I started my exam 20 minutes late (so my exam time is actually 70mins only). Don't be frightened with the complicated theories on the notes, since this is a introductory course, ONLY basic concepts will be tested.

reviews.comment_teaching: Both professors are nice.  I can't comment much on the teaching part as I skipped most of the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorial attendance (30%)
You will need to complete a worksheet (10MCs) for every tutorial.  The TA will show you the answer at the end of the lesson.  Those questions are extremely important as most of them will appear in the final exam.

Final Exam (70%)
You will be given 2 hours to complete 110 MCs, and most of the students left after 30 minutes.  The MCs are pretty straightforward, so you just need to memorize all the ppt slides and tutorial notes.  

The grade is unexpectedly good.  I just revised the night before and got a grade that is quite satisfactory.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light compare with other courses.  Just make sure that you attend all tutorial lessons.

reviews.comment_teaching:
NG, Yee Fai
The professor speaks good English. He lecture is quite easy to understand, but he talks super slow which makes you want to double/triple speed his entire lecture. He demonstrates some simple experiments which helps the understanding of the content (a bit).

FOREMAN, Bradley Alan
The professor speaks good English as you can notice from his name. I only attended one lecutre of his, but it was boring and I fell asleep without even knowing.

TUTORIALS
Literally no point of going, but you have to attend since attendace counts 30% of the total mark.

reviews.comment_content: The content is not that hard as the understanding and memorising of those difficult formulae and equations are not required. The materials taught are just basic physic. So even you didn't study physic for your DSE you can still handle the course.

reviews.author: slds9d
reviews.comment_content: The content is very broad and long, there are like 20 ppt in total for the whole course (some ppt contain around up to 80 slides). The content consists nearly everything of physics.

reviews.comment_grading: I think is fair. I didn't attend any lecture at all and studied 2 weeks before the exam , I got A- at the end (I think I got around 70-80 questions correct out of 100 in final exam). You should memorize all the questions from tutorial sessions which composite around 30%-50% of the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload at all, just attend all the tutorial sessions which usually last for 30 mins only. The TA will give you around 20 mins for doing the questions which would show up in the final exam and remaining 10 mins for answers checking.  The only workload is to memorize all the tutorial questions (around 100 questions) and make sure you have enough time to prepare the exam earlier like 2 weeks (if you want A range). It's hard to dead fight for this course since the content is quite long.

reviews.author: scccccc
reviews.title: Syllabus has changed!
reviews.comment_content:
The syllabus is changed this year. No calculations is needed in this course. All are memorizing. I dropped Physics in secondary 5 and have some basic knowledge about Physics. I thought this course should be easy to me. HOWEVER, all of my knowledge is useless in this course. I just noticed that the content of the new syllabus in this course are all DSE Physics ELECTIVE syllabus, which students who didn't take Physics DSE exam are not expected to know. Don't think that you dropped Physics and you can get good grade in this course easily.

These are topics covered in this course:

1. History, Methodology and Bird View
2. Energy
3. Entertainment and Various Daily Applications
4.  New Materials and Physics
5. Microscopy and Nanotechnology
6. Information Technology and Physics
7. Medical Applications
8. Disasters
9. Elementary Particles and Standard Model
10. Universe and Cosmology
11. Environmental Issues
12. Future and Unsolved Problems
reviews.comment_teaching: Boring generally. Extremely hypnotic. The English of DR Ng Yee Fai is quite easy to follow IF you don't fall asleep in class. But for professor Lin Nian, I couldn't understand wt he talked for about 4 lessons so I finally gave up his class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance 30% (Tutorial)
Final Exam 70% MC questions

For the final exam, there were about half(???)questions are from tutorial questions. Please memorize all the tutorial questions before exam. You can already get a C+ if you only memorize the tutorial questions.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload. Only final exam and attendance. Just attend all tutorial classes to take attendance is ok.

reviews.author: oscarswt
reviews.comment_content: PHYS 1001 covers quite a lot of topics. As I remember, there will be around 24 lecture notes, which contains approximately 80 pages for each. Personally, some of them are quite interesting, such as medical application. However, tons of hard facts are needed to be memorized.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture is quite boring, the professor repeats what the powerpoint is about in a dull way. Some experiments will be presented tho, maybe a few times throughout the whole semester.
reviews.comment_grading: It really depends on your memorizing skill on hard facts, there will be no mid term exam but one final exam. The exam paper are all multiple choices, most of them are hard facts, such as how many degree is the sun, the size of an atom. No calculation is needed throughout the whole exam, which maybe a good news for some of you. But please sure you can memorize a lot of hard fact for this course.
reviews.comment_workload: There is nearly no workload. No homework is needed and the lecture will not take any attendance. The only thing you need to do is attending the tutorial every week.

2-4 lectures for each topic (except only 1 lecture for energy).
one tutorial per week that counts attendance but you only "do" mc questions there so it was quite a waste of time.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Overall, the lectures are dull and makes people fall asleep especially when they were 9am classes. The contents were quite boring as well. In fact, most students skipped the lectures (LIN said in the very fist lecture that students can feel free to skip lessons lol).
One good thing about the lectures is the experiments/demonstrations that woke students up. They were also helpful for understanding certain concepts.

NG teaches better than LIN. He spoke in a more organised manner that was easy to follow and provided detailed and organised notes. TBH, with his notes I could skip all the lectures and still managed to prepare the final well enough.

LIN has a bad English accent that was kinda hard to follow, his way of teaching was quite messy as well. Unlike NG, LIN's notes lacked explanations and details but were filled with pictures, which were somehow meaningless if you didn't go to class or didn't jot notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorials (by attendance) 30%
Final exam 70%

They count your attendance as long as you were able to hand in the MC worksheet.
Since most people attends every tutorial, the final exam determines your fate.

I thought I did pretty well in the final but ended up getting a B only, don't know why as they didn't tell us our marks.

reviews.author: Hongjj
reviews.comment_content:
quite interesting actually, i thought i have to memorize many equation and many abstract thing in physics but turns out that we DONT have to memorize any equation. The content is mostly about the physics of the daily appliance, some natural phenomenon and some future technology (nanotech, quantum computer...etc) which are very relatable and should be engrossing if you are sort of into finding out how things around you work.

Topics covered in this course
1.Energy issues and physics (easy)
   
2.Entertainment and physics (understand the principle and you will do fine in exam)
   
3.New materials and physics (the first half is easy if you study chemistry in high school, the next part is a bit tough though)

4.Microscopy and Nanotechnology (something that is not so easy to understand if you skip the lecture)

5.Information technology and physics (many things to memorize and understand, the link below will help you if you dont understand the quantum computer part (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JhHMJCUmq28)

6.Medical/health and physics
-mere memorization

7.Environmental issues and physics
-basic geog stuff and mixed with some primary school general studies

8.Disasters and physics
-asteroid/earthquake waves/ nuclear bomb and accident

9.Universe and Cosmology
-not that hard if you are interested in the phenomenon of the universe, how the universe form  and how it end

10.Elementary particles and standard model
i dont understand a single thing said in lecture in this chapter, i gave up this chapter but the exam questions about this chapter is just tutorial questions lol
reviews.comment_teaching:
2 instructors : Prof. LIN, Nian, Dr. NG, Yee Fai
tutor: QIN, Xianan

Prof. LIN, Nian:
he teaches :
intro and outlook of physics
New materials and physics
Microscopy and Nanotechnology
Information technology and physics

-his English is not quite hard to understand compare to other Chinese professor. he always ask us question to make sure we understand but u know, it always ended up in silence...

- his powerpoint is fine i guess. mostly point form though 60% of the ppt is pictures and quotes from Einstein - - and also many nobel prize winners. the number of slides is quite scary tbh ( on average 80 slides per ppt)



Dr. NG, Yee Fai:
he teaches:
Energy issues and physics
Entertainment and physics
Medical/health and physics
Environmental issues and physics
Disasters and physics

- his english is clear, but he talks too slow. i fell asleep every lecture for some reason ....
- each slide is filled with a sea of words -.- and there is also about 70 slides per ppt
- attending his lecture would be helpful


QIN, Xianan
tutor of my tutorial
-told us  thing outside the lecture notes, but he talks so quietly that sometimes i missed what he said
-nothing special so no comment here.


the guest lecturers:
- there is no use attending their lecture cause that wont appear in the exam.

I hope in this course you will find:

reviews.author: C.ko
reviews.comment_content:
The content of the course is listed below.

-Energy and Power
- Atoms and heat
-Force and Gravity
-Nuclear power
-electric magnestism
-Waves
-Light
-Quantum Physics
-The Universe
-Relativity

Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to
--- appreciate the wonders of physics and its power to understand the mechanism of the Universe: from the microscopic world to the macroscopic world;
--- develop literacy in the physical and technological innovations of the modern society;
--- recognize the empirical, theoretical, and philosophical foundation of physics, and to think scientific and critical in terms of the language of physics;
--- employ the knowledge of physics to explain some daily-life physical phenomena, and to solve simple physics-related problems;
---establish and realize the connection of physics with other scientific disciplines, technology, inventions, and the society;
be aware of the impact of physics on the society, ethics, economy, and the environment, and to cultivate an attitude of being a responsible citizen.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is quite good. The professor explains every concepts clearly and sometimes, in a funny way. It might be hard to follow somehow, but reviewing the lecture notes and attending the tutorials every week would definitely help. There are 4 documentary videos in the whole course and students are expected to watch the videos in order to gain marks for iprs. (have to answer questions through iprs which counts 10% of your final grade)
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fine.

Personal Response System (PRS): 10% (for 4 documentaries)
Quizzes (held at tutorials): 30% (total 2 quizzes, 30 minutes each)
Final Examination (mandatory): 60% (2hr 30min)
* Quizzes: Multiple-choices Questions and Short Questions.

* Final Exam: Multiple-choices Questions and Short Questions.

* Close-book and close-notes; calculator required; Internet access NOT allowed.

* 1 cheat sheet (2 pages, A4 size) is allowed for quizzes. 3 cheat sheets (6 pages, A4 size) are allowed for the Final Exam.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload. Only final and 2 quizzes. Attending the lectures with documentary videos is a must.

reviews.comment_content:
好多課 但考試淨係出MC 唔算好深
同埋好多都係係tutor d ws抽翻出黎,背曬至少有B

reviews.comment_workload: 0 WORKLOAD,無Mid term,asm, pj,只有考試

reviews.author: JJJJJJJ
reviews.title: 內容多但唔難
reviews.comment_content: 內容都幾多下, 但唔係話好難理解, 而且好多都係日常生活會見到或者用到, 唔洗計數, 主要學理論. e.g. 咩係potential energy, kinetic energy; sources of energy分為咩 (e.g, solar power); 咩係thermodynamics, electromagnetism etc. 內容所涉及範圍很多.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. NG & Prof. LIN教得唔錯, 聽完佢地既堂, 返去睇多一次, 其實都大致上記得lecture notes既內容. physics咁抽象既野至少我都聽得明佢地講咩
reviews.comment_grading:
only mc! no mid-term no assignment!

70% final exam.
30% tutorial

真心30% tutorial係人人都有, 只要係唔走tutorial, 因為有出席就有分.
final exam全mc! 真係想考你明唔明 concept而唔係考你串字. 而且有D題目係tutorial都做過. 不過因為程度唔係太難, 所以條curve都拉到幾高, 合格無問題, 但想higher grade就要溫熟多小小.
reviews.comment_workload:
only final exam & tutorial.
無任何assignment. 算係最輕鬆一科.

reviews.author: jaychou
reviews.comment_content: This course has a wide range of content about Physics. From the classical physics and even quantum physics. It takes time to digest and understand all the content. But the note may include some online video and it helps a lot for me to get the full picture of it and also arouses my interest about physics. to be honest the final exam is extremely easy. you may not know how everything works but recite the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr Ng is funny and patient to teach every single concept. his english is good and you may not get lost during the lesson. but prof Lin may have some accent but still ok. both of them will demonstrate some experiment in the lecture. it is quite fun. there are some guest speakers in some lectures talking about some advanced physics but i skipped those lessons so  im not sure about that. and the last few lectures there are no more lectures but a documentary. prof played the documentary in the lessons and the content of it is also examined. but this makes the lectures more interesting.
reviews.comment_grading: this course is quite easy in fact. i  study hard before the final and got a B+
reviews.comment_workload: no workload at all. you just need to attend the tutorial every week and study before the final exam is ok.

reviews.author: hann
reviews.comment_content: No assignments or projects at all, the material is interesting and introduces a lot of up to date technology discoveries. Lectures do not check attendance but tutorials do.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is a passionate and humorous person, is really good at explaining concepts (sometimes even through experiments in lectures). However the Instructional Assistant‘s(NG, Ka Long) tutorials  does not introduce any new knowledge. He only answers a few multiple choice question in class and that's all. He shows no teaching passion and is extremely rude.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is solely based on attendance(tut) and the final exam. There is no midterm exam and no homework at all. I attended all the classes, I do not know my score on final exam yet, but I got a A.
reviews.comment_workload: With basically no work at all, the only  "workload" is attending classes. As long as you attend classes regularly the final exam won't be to much of a problem.

reviews.comment_content: A lot of topics but without calculation and very little about physics theory
reviews.comment_teaching: Boring, esp LIN Nian's lecture
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Tutorial attendance, attendance can be taken by the others, quite a lot of people do so.

70% Final Examination, about half questions are taken out from the tutorial multiple choice questions

Only grade, without marks of both parts
reviews.comment_workload:
Lectures are not compulsory but the tutorial is required.

Just recite the tutorial mc and the large words in the lecture notes and have a brief concept

Take less than three hours to do revision before final exam

reviews.author: Andy HK
reviews.comment_content:
The content is in huge amount and extremely difficult such as relativity.
Topics include energy and power, atom and heat, force and gravity, nuclear power, electricity and magnetism, waves, light, quantum physics, the universe and relativity.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is not good because the content is very rich, so the concepts are not clearly explained in the lecture. For tutorial, the teaching quality is slightly better and we will know the main point of the quiz or exam. Tutorial is of paramount importance, so full attendance is a must.
There will be some online exercise on canvas but do not count for any marks.
One past paper will be uploaded on canvas for you to practice but the level of the practice paper and the actual final exam paper is extremely different.
Additional 2 exercises will also be provided before the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is not very well.
reviews.comment_workload: It has 2 quizzes and final examination. 10% of the marks are from iPRS questions after watching a video. The videos are very long and have no subtitle, so you need to pay attention for a long time which is very tired and stressful.

reviews.author: Roy
reviews.title: Excellent Grading
reviews.comment_content:
It's a course which introduces all the physics topics in a simple manner. Starting from energy, forces to wave and light and even quantum physics and relativity. The topics after quantum physics are a bit hard for understanding. But others are as simple as junior secondary school science. You do not even need to think and you can obtain full mark in the quizzes.

There will also be some documentary to arouse your interest in physics, which is quite entertaining. You may sleep if you find it bored. PRS questions will be asked after each documentaries. Just see the others' answers if you slept.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. NG is an excellent professor in teaching physics. He can stimulate your thinking and provoke your interest in studying the topics. Although he has monotonic voice, you can find the interesting parts if you keep your brain running in the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
Excellent grading for a course in UST.
I am not an expert in physics and I don't have any background in physics.

Quizes : a bit above mean
Final: mean

Grade: B

Prof. NG said that he would use many ways for grading, not just making curves and cut-off. He promised to benefit everyone and he would come up with the best overall performance. If you try your best in this courses, grade is not a part need to be worried.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair.

No HWs. No midterm. No labs.

Just bi-weekly quizzes, PRS and final exam.

I suggest you keep on studying if you do not have any basic ideas about physics. As you need some times to clear the concepts. But it is still manageable if you study the day before exams.
